q: The first step in JWT verification is to Decode the _____ to check the algorithm.
One risk of using RSA is choosing a weak (small) public _____.
The 'PS' in PS256 stands for Probabilistic _____ Scheme.
Signing a JWT ensures _____ of the payload.
One benefit of JWTs is that they are _____ across different domains (CORS).
The 'cty' header parameter stands for _____ Type, used when the payload allows multiple types.
A JWT normally consists of _____ parts separated by dots.
What are the three parts of a JWT?
How are the parts of a JWT separated?
What encoding does JWT use for its parts?
Is the payload of a JWT encrypted by default?
o: No, it is only encoded (Base64Url), so anyone can read it

q: What is typically in the JWT Header?
What does 'alg' stand for in Header?
What does 'typ' stand for in Header?
What is the 'Payload' of a JWT?
o: Contains Claims (statements about an entity/user) and additional data
A key-value pair asserting information (e.g. user_id: 123)

q: RSA signatures are deterministic (PKCS#1 v1.5), meaning the same inputs produce the _____ signature.
JWTs are often used in _____ architectures to pass user context between services.
HMAC algorithms (like HS256) involve a _____ secret key.

o: A set of predefined claims (like iss, exp, sub) recommended for interoperability

q: If the algorithm header does not match the expected key type, the library should throw an _____.
If nested signing or encryption is employed, the 'cty' header must be set to _____.
The first part of a JWT is the _____.
If the algorithm in the header does not match the expected one, verification should _____.

o: Subject (whom the token refers to, e.g. user ID)
Audience (who is intended to consume the token)
Expiration Time (after which token is invalid)
Not Before (token is not valid before this time)
Issued At (time when token was created)
JWT ID (unique identifier for the token)
To limit the window of opportunity for a stolen token

q: What happens if you change the payload of a signed JWT?
o: The signature verification fails (unless you re-sign it with the secret key)

q: What is the 'Signature' part used for?
o: To verify that the sender is who it says it is and to ensure that the message wasn't changed along the way

q: ECDSA signatures (ES256) involve a random component, so signing the same data twice produces _____ signatures.
The size of a JWT can be an issue if too many _____ are added.
The 'jku' header parameter stands for JWK Set _____.
The second part of a JWT is the _____.
JWT libraries often provide a 'verify' function that takes the token and the _____.
In HS256, who knows the secret key?
o: Both the issuer and the verifier (Shared Secret)

q: In RS256, who knows the private key?
o: Only the issuer (Verifier uses public key)

q: Which is better for public APIs: HS256 or RS256?
o: RS256 (allows anyone to verify with public key without risking the private key)
ECDSA using P-256 and SHA-256 (Elliptic Curve)
Smaller keys and faster signing for same security level
No signature (insecure, used for debugging or internal trusted networks)
Attackers can strip signature and set alg to none, bypassing verification if not handled correctly

q: Verifying the signature ensures the token has not been _____.

o: Explicitly whitelist allowed algorithms on the server (e.g. only RS256)
Nothing, dots are separators, not part of the encoded string

q: Is Base64Url the same as Base64?
o: Similar, but '+' becomes '-', '/' becomes '_', and padding '=' is omitted

q: NIST recommends a minimum RSA key size of _____ bits for legacy compatibility.
Large JWTs can exceed the maximum header size of web _____.
Why use Base64Url instead of Base64?
o: To be URL-safe (can be passed in URL parameters without escaping)

q: The third part of a JWT is the _____.
The 'jwk' header parameter allows embedding the JSON Web _____ directly in the header.
If a JWT has 3 parts, how many dots does it have?

o: JSON Web Signature (Signed JWT is technically a JWS)

q: Can a JWT be both signed and encrypted?
o: Yes, typically sign then encrypt (Nested JWT)

q: A signature mismatch indicates the token was tampered with or the wrong _____ was used.
Where are JWTs usually sent in HTTP requests?
What is the format of the Authorization header?

o: Indicates the token type (Bearer means 'whoever bears this token has access')

q: Can JWTs be stored in cookies?
o: Yes, often HttpOnly cookies to prevent XSS

q: Can JWTs be stored in LocalStorage?
o: Yes, but vulnerable to XSS (malicious scripts can read them)

q: What is the size limit of a JWT?
o: In practice, limited by HTTP header size limits (usually ~8kb), but can get large

q: For new systems, an RSA key size of _____ bits or larger is preferred.

o: Stateless (Self-contained, server doesn't need to store session data)

q: If a JWT is too large for a cookie, it might be stored in _____ Storage.
What is the main advantage of stateless auth?
o: Scalability (any server can verify token without database lookup)

q: The different parts of a JWT are separated by a _____ character.
In RS256, the _____ key is used to sign the token.
To verify an HS256 signature, you need the same _____ key used to sign it.
The 'x5u' header parameter points to a X.509 _____ URL.
What is the main disadvantage of stateless JWT?
o: Cannot instantly revoke a token (must wait for expiry or build a blacklist)
Client deletes token; Server cannot force logout unless expiry/blacklist is checked
A list of JTI (JWT IDs) that are blacklisted before expiry

q: Does checking a revocation list make JWT stateful?
o: Yes, effectively adds a state check (lookup) to verification
An access token that expires quickly (e.g. 15 mins) to minimize theft risk
A long-lived token used to obtain new access tokens when they expire

q: Where should Refresh Token be stored?
o: Ideally HttpOnly Secure Cookie (to prevent XSS theft)

q: The 'jti' (JWT ID) claim can be used to prevent _____ attacks by tracking used tokens.
Can a Refresh Token be revoked?
o: Yes, usually tracked in database, so can be revoked to cut off access
Issuing a new refresh token every time the old one is used (and invalidating the old one)

q: What does Refresh Token Rotation prevent?
o: Token theft reuse (if stolen token is used, rotation detects mismatch and revokes all)

q: Unlike cookies, JWTs do not automatically handle _____ management.

o: Not directly (encoded), but can be easily decoded (e.g. jwt.io)

q: Should sensitive info (secret key) be in payload?
o: Never, payload is visible to anyone

q: In RS256, the _____ key is used to verify the token.
Should PII (Personally Identifiable Info) be in JWT?
o: Avoid if possible, or encrypt it (JWE), since JWT might travel through logs/browsers

q: The 'x5c' parameters contains a chain of X.509 _____.

o: Key ID (hint indicating which key was used to secure the JWS)
Allows Key Rotation (server can look up correct key version)
JSON Web Key (JSON structure representing a cryptographic key)
Endpoint where a server publishes its public keys (JWK Set)

q: How does a client verify RS256 JWT from Google?
o: Fetches Google's JWKS, finds key matching 'kid', verifies signature

q: To verify an RS256 signature, you need the signer's _____ key.
Does JWT spec support custom claims?
o: Yes, you can add any key-value pair to the payload (e.g. 'role': 'admin')

q: What is 'Collision Resistant Namespace' for claims?
o: Using a URI as claim name (e.g. 'https://myapp.com/role') to avoid conflicts
Verifying the 'aud' claim matches the receiving service
Token should be rejected (it was not meant for this service)

q: Signing does NOT provide confidentiality; anyone can _____ the token.
EdDSA (Ed25519) is a modern Edwards-curve Digital Signature Algorithm that is very _____.

o: Yes, using tools like jwt.io debugger

q: The Header typically contains the token type and the _____ used.
Is the order of claims in payload important?
Elliptic Curve algorithms (ES256) produce _____ signatures than RSA for the same security level.
The 'x5t' parameter is a base64url encoded SHA-1 _____ of the certificate.
What library is commonly used for JWT in Node.js?
What does verifying a JWT involve?
o: Checking signature validity, checking expiry, checking issuer/audience
Small time window (e.g. 5 min) allowed for clock differences when checking exp/nbf
Because server clocks are rarely perfectly synchronized
JSON Web Algorithms (registry of algs like RS256, HS256)
Yes, JWE supports compression (DEF), JWS technically can but rare

q: Which is more performant: JWT or Reference Tokens?
o: JWT is faster for API (no DB lookup), Reference Tokens are faster to revoke
Yes, typically larger than a random string session ID

q: Can you use JWT for email verification?
o: Yes, sign a token with user ID and send link; verify on click

q: Using HMAC requires distributing the secret to all services that need to _____ tokens.
The 'sub' claim usually contains the user _____.
Is JWT a standard or a framework?
If the 'exp' claim is in the past, the token is _____.

o: Yes, a signed JWT can be the payload of an encrypted JWT (Nested)
Content Type (used in Nested JWTs to indicate payload is another JWT)

q: The algorithm is specified in the header key _____.
If 'alg' is 'none', the signature portion of the JWT is _____.

o: No, can be used in WebSockets, MQTT, etc.

q: The 'crit' header parameter lists headers that MUST be understood using _____ extensions.
What if you lose the private key for RS256?
o: You cannot sign valid tokens anymore; must generate new pair and redistribute public key

q: What if the secret key for HS256 is leaked?
o: Attacker can forge any token; must rotate secret immediately

q: Can a JWT be used for CSRF protection?
o: If stored in localStorage and sent via header, it is immune to CSRF (unlike cookies)

q: What is the downside of localStorage for JWT?
What is the downside of Cookies for JWT?
o: Vulnerable to CSRF (needs SameSite, CSRF tokens)

q: What is the best storage for JWT in browser?
o: It depends (Safety vs Convenience): HttpOnly Cookie is safest against XSS

q: Distributing a shared secret increases the risk of key _____.
Can you use JWT for 'Forgot Password' flow?
o: Yes, short-lived signed token in link

q: What is a 'Brute Force' attack on JWT?
o: Attempting to guess the signing secret (HMAC)

q: How to prevent JWT Brute Force?
o: Use strong, long, random secrets (at least 256 bits)

q: The token type is specified in the header key _____.
A Nested JWT is a JWT that is signed and then _____.
Using a weak shared secret allows attackers to _____ force the key offline.
Registered claim names are only _____ characters long to keep tokens small.
What is the default expiration of a JWT?
o: There is no default; issuer decides (e.g. 1 hour, 1 year)

q: If the current time is before the 'nbf' claim, the token is not yet _____.

o: Attacker forces server to use HMAC with the Public Key as the secret
Attacker changes alg to HS256 and signs token using the server's known Public Key as the HMAC secret
Validate that the algorithm in the header matches the expected algorithm for the key used
Critical (lists headers that MUST be understood by verifier or reject token)
JWK Set URL (URI referring to a resource for a set of JSON-encoded public keys)
Attacker can host their own keys and point 'jku' to their server

q: With asymmetric keys, public keys can be hosted at a well-known _____ endpoint.

o: Whitelist allowed hosts/URLs for these headers

q: NumericDate in JWT (like exp) is the count of seconds since the Unix _____.

o: X.509 URL (URI referring to X.509 public key certificate)
The standard JWT format: Header.Payload.Signature (URL safe)
A verbose JSON format allowing multiple signatures (protected/unprotected headers)

q: The 'kid' header parameter stands for Key _____.

o: When you need multiple signatures (e.g. signed by multiple parties)

q: If you encrypt first and then sign, the signature is over the _____ text.
The 'iat' claim can be used to reject tokens that were issued too _____ ago.

o: The payload is not included in the JWS structure (kept separate)
Signing large files/data without embedding them in the token header/sig
A JWS with 'alg':'none' and empty signature
AES-128 Key Wrap (algorithm for encrypting keys)

q: JWKS stands for JSON Web Key _____.
StringOrURI is a JSON string value, with the additional requirement that if it contains a ':', it is a _____.
Clock _____ allows for a small time difference between signers and verifiers.

o: Content Encryption Key (symmetric key used to encrypt the payload)
Key Encryption Key (key used to encrypt the CEK)
Authentication Tag (verifies integrity of ciphertext and header)

q: Key _____ is the practice of regularly changing signing keys.
The 'nbf' (Not Before) claim helps in handling clock _____ issues between servers.

o: Yes, typically RSA-OAEP to encrypt the CEK
Compressing payload before encryption to save space (zip header)

q: Some libraries allow providing a 'buffer' or 'window' for _____ time validation.

o: Compression can leak info about plaintext side-channels (risk in JWE/TLS)

q: Should exact error messages be returned for JWT?
o: No, use generic 'Invalid Token' to prevent information leakage (e.g. signature vs expiry)
Yes, anyone can decode Base64Url (unless JWE)
A random string reference that means nothing to the client (must check DB)

q: A JWK represents a cryptographic key in a _____ structure.
UnSecured JWS is used when integrity protection is not needed or provided by _____.

o: JWT = Self-contained, larger; Opaque = Reference, smaller, revokable
Yes, standard way to pass authorization info

q: What if JWT is too big for header?
o: Request might be dropped by load balancers/servers (431 Request Header Fields Too Large)
Use shorter claim names, remove non-essential claims, use ECDSA

q: Registered claims are predefined claims like iss, exp, and _____.

o: Claims that refer to an external source (endpoint) rather than including value directly
Header used for Distributed Claims source definitions

q: A typical clock skew allowance is a few _____.
When rotating keys, the server must support verifying tokens signed with the _____ key for a grace period.

o: Header defining locations to fetch distributed claims

q: Public claim names should be collision-resistant, often by using a _____ format.

o: No, but highly recommended for identifying the user

q: What is 'Clock Tolerance' defaults in libs?
What is 'JWT Best Current Practices' RFC?

o: No, it explicitly advises against it

q: Validating the signature is computationally _____ than decoding Base64.
The 'use' parameter in a JWK indicates whether the key is for signing (sig) or _____ (enc).

o: Yes, verify 'typ' header to prevent confusion attacks (e.g. JWT vs Access Token)

q: To debug a JWT, you can copy it to _____ for easy decoding.

o: A token that can be read as multiple formats (e.g. valid JWT and valid X.509)
Can bypass security filters checking for specific formats

q: Can you sign a JWT with a certificate?
o: Yes, using the private key associated with the certificate
A hash of a certificate or key

q: Public claims can be defined by anyone but should avoid _____.
How to invalidate a specific JWT?
o: Short expiry, or store JTI in blacklist (require DB check)

q: Can you change JWT expiry after signing?
What is 'Sliding Window' session with JWT?
o: Issuing a new JWT (with new expiry) on every valid request near expiry

q: PS256 (RSASSA-PSS) is a probabilistic signature scheme, generally considered more secure than _____.
Collision-resistant names often use namespaces, e.g. 'https://example.com/_____'.

o: OIDC concept: Public = same sub for all clients; Pairwise = different sub per client
Yes, if encoded (Base64) within JSON string values

q: The 'kty' parameter in a JWK specifies the key _____ (e.g., RSA, EC).
Validating the 'iss' claim ensures the token came from a trusted _____.

o: CBOR Web Token (efficient binary equivalent of JWT for IoT)

q: The signature verifies that the sender has the corresponding _____ key.
To avoid DoS, authentication servers should _____ limit signature verification attempts.

o: CBOR Object Signing and Encryption (like JOSE for JWT)
Javascript Object Signing and Encryption (JWS/JWE/JWK/JWA suite)

q: Private claims are custom claims agreed upon by producer and _____.
Is JWT header encrypted in JWS?
Is JWT header encrypted in JWE?
o: No, usually authenticated but visible (to know how to decrypt)

q: Can you hide the header in JWE?
o: No, header is needed to process the token

q: A common vulnerability involves an attacker changing 'alg' from RS256 to _____.

o: Additional Authenticated Data (integrity protected but not encrypted)

q: Private claim names are subject to _____ if different parties use the same name for different things.

o: No hard limit, but practically limited by total size
Invalid JSON behavior (last one usually wins), avoid it
JSON Serialization optimized for single signature (removing 'signatures' array wrapper)

q: If an attacker modifies the payload, the signature verification will _____.

o: RSASSA-PSS using SHA-256 (Probabilistic Signature Scheme, better than PKCS#1 v1.5)

q: The signature of a symmetric algorithm is generated using a _____ key.

o: Edwards-curve Digital Signature Algorithm (Ed25519 - fast & secure)

q: Is Ed25519 supported in all JWT libraries?
o: Increasingly yes, but less common than RS256/HS256 in legacy systems

q: The 'x5t#S256' header parameter is a SHA-256 thumbprint of the _____.
Validating the 'aud' claim ensures the token is intended for this _____.
Is JWT a structure or a token type?
o: Technically a specific JSON-based claim format, often used AS a token

q: The signature is used to verify the sender and ensure the message hasn't _____.
What is 'Unprotected Header' in JWS JSON?
o: Header parameters that are NOT integrity protected by signature
Attacker can modify them without breaking signature

q: In the Alg confusion attack, the server uses its public key as the HMAC _____ secret.
JOSE stands for Javascript Object Signing and _____.

o: Indicates if payload is Base64Url encoded (default true, can be false for detached non-encoded)

q: If b64=false, can you embed binary directly?
o: No, JSON still requires valid characters

q: In a 'cut and paste' attack, an attacker combines a valid header/signature with a different _____.
When using RSA, the signature is generated with the _____ key.

o: Using a signed JWT to authenticate a client (instead of client_secret)
Avoids sending shared secret over network; uses public key crypto

q: Can JWT be used as an access token?
Can JWT be used as an ID token?
Difference: ID Token vs Access Token (JWT)?
o: ID Token is for Client (identifies user); Access Token is for API (authorizes access)

q: To create the signature, you need the encoded header, encoded payload, and a _____.

o: Yes, to ensure it wasn't tampered with

q: Using a key management service (KMS) abstracts the complexity of key _____ and rotation.
To prevent 'alg' confusion, servers should enforce a whitelist of allowed _____.
You should check if the token has been revoked, often by checking a _____ list.
A JWT with 'alg' set to 'none' is considered _____.
Actually, changing the payload invalidates the signature unless the signature is also _____.
When using RSA, the signature is verified with the _____ key.

o: Regularly changing the cryptographic keys (signing keys) used to sign JWTs
Limits the impact of a compromised key (old keys become invalid eventually)

q: How does a client handle Key Rotation (RS256)?
o: It re-fetches the JWKS (cached) when it encounters an unknown 'kid' in the JWT header
A token that can only be used by the specific client for whom it was issued (prevents replay if stolen)
Binding the access token to the client's TLS client certificate (Certificate Bound Access Tokens)
Token includes hash of client cert (cnf claim); API verifies connection uses that cert
Confirmation (used for proof-of-possession, containing key hash or cert hash)
Demonstrating Proof-of-Possession (application-layer mechanism to bind tokens to a key held by client)
Client generates a key pair, signs a DPoP header on every request; Server verifies signature and binds token to public key
Works at application layer (doesn't require complex TLS infrastructure or client cert management)

q: When using 'jwk' in header, the server must verify the key is _____.
Secrets for HS256 should be long, random, and keep _____.

o: Attacker intercepts a valid JWT and uses it again to access the API

q: However, if the attacker sends a valid token signed by a different key (and the server accepts that key), it might _____.
How to mitigate Replay Attack for JWT?
o: Use HTTPS (prevent interception), Short expiry, Sender Constraining (DPoP/mTLS)

q: A 'b64' header parameter set to false implies payload is not _____ encoded.
What is 'JTI' (JWT ID) used for in replay protection?
o: To track unique tokens; can protect against ONE-TIME use if server stores used JTIs

q: Does standard JWT verify JTI uniqueness?
o: No, that requires stateful storage on server
Authorized Party (the client ID that requested the token)

q: If a JWE is received, it must be _____ before verification.

o: When the token is used by a party different from the audience (e.g. mobile app calling API)
'sub' is the standard registered claim for subject; 'user_id' would be a custom claim (redundant)
Yes, but unique IDs (UUID) are better (emails change, IDs don't)
A specialized 'sub' value unique to a client-user pair (privacy feature to prevent tracking)
Scopes are high-level access areas requested by client; Permissions are granular rights granted to user

q: Should the JWT contain all user permissions?
o: Cautiously; too many permissions bloat the token size (hit header limits)

q: The minimum recommended secret length for HS256 is _____ bits.
What if permissions don't fit in JWT?
o: Use the JWT to look up permissions in a database/cache or call an endpoint (hybrid approach)

q: A 'kid' (Key ID) is useful when the server has multiple signing _____.
Simply checking if a signature is valid is not enough; you must also check _____ of the claims.
Strictly validating the 'iss' claim helps ensure the token was signed by the expected _____.

o: A term sometimes used for phantom tokens (opaque externally, JWT internally)

q: Detached content JWS means the payload is transported _____ from the JWS.

o: Client gets a random string (reference); API calls Introspection Endpoint to validate it
Immediate revocation, no large payload on wire, hides internal info
Increased latency (network call to introspection endpoint for every request)
Yes, usually for a short time (e.g. 1-5 mins) to balance performance and revocation speed

q: What is 'BFF' (Backend For Frontend) auth pattern?
o: BFF handles tokens (stores in session/cookie), Client only sees session cookie (Token-less frontend)

q: Why is BFF preferred for SPAs now?
o: Significantly more secure than storing tokens in browser (Local/SessionStorage)

q: Base64Url is similar to Base64 but uses different characters for _____ and slash.

o: Controls when cookies are sent with cross-site requests (Strict, Lax, None)

q: For auth cookies, what SameSite value is best?
o: Strict or Lax (prevents CSRF in most cases)
Using a hidden iframe to refresh token without user interaction (deprecated due to ITP/3rd party cookie blocks)

q: Libraries usually handle base64 decoding and signature _____ automatically.

o: Refresh Tokens with Rotation (handled by worker or BFF)
Browser feature (Safari) blocking 3rd party cookies, affecting default OIDC flows

q: Using the 'jwk' header to embed the public key requires strictly validating the _____.
Key rotation involves handling both the old and new key during the _____ period.
The 'x5c' field can provide the X.509 certificate chain used to _____ the key.
In Compact Serialization, a Detached JWS omits the payload between the two _____.

o: Yes, 'nonce' claim binds token to a specific client session (mitigates replay)

q: Specifically, checking 'exp' (Expiration Time) and 'nbf' (Not Before) is _____.

o: Access Token Hash (included in ID token to verify the access token was issued with it)
Code Hash (verifies authorization code in Hybrid Flow)
Token can be valid for multiple audiences (array of strings)

q: If 'aud' is array, do you need 'azp'?
o: Yes, typically to specify WHICH client in the audience group requested it
Injecting a public key in the header (if server trusts header key blindly)
Confusing HMAC and RSA keys (Algorithm Confusion)
If 'kid' is used as a filename lookup, attacker might use '../../' to read other files
Sanitize input, don't use direct filesystem calls, use a DB or allow-list map
Yes, checks if token is encrypted

q: What if 'crit' header has unknown tag?
The 'jku' header allows fetching keys from a URL, but exposes the system to _____ attacks if unchecked.
Self-signed certificates in 'x5c' should generally be _____ unless explicitly trusted.

o: When you define custom headers that are security-critical and must be processed

q: JSON Serialization allows identifying which key is used for each _____.
Using 'iss' allows an API to trust multiple identity _____.

o: Gateway validates external token, then passes internal JWT (or same JWT) to services

q: Never trust the payload data until the _____ is verified.

o: Yes, Zero Trust: verify signature and expiry even internally

q: How to distribute public keys to microservices?
If 'exp' is missing, the token might be considered valid _____ (unless policy says otherwise).

o: A proxy container (e.g. Envoy) next to app that handles auth/validation offloading
Using Open Policy Agent to validate JWT claims against policies (AuthZ)
Yes, native support for JWT verification

q: What is 'Rego' policy for JWT example?
o: Allow if token.payload.role == 'admin' AND token.exp > now
Functions that run on login pipeline (modify JWT, add claims, deny access)
Use URI format (https://my.app/color) to avoid collision
Depends on content; if PII is inside, must handle correctly (encryption/minimization)

q: Can you delete a JWT from a user's browser remotely?
o: No, only client can delete it (unless revoked on server side effectively)

q: What is 'Sign out' best practice with JWT?
o: Client clears storage AND calls server to revoke refresh token

q: Using a Hardware Security Module (HSM) protects the _____ key from extraction.
HS256 is acceptable for _____ services where the auth server and resource server are the same.
The 'protected' member in JSON Serialization contains Base64Url encoded _____ parameters.
The 'aud' claim can be a single string or an _____ of strings.

o: Invalidating all tokens for a user (e.g. key rotation or revocation by user ID)

q: How to implement Global Sign Out?
o: Increment a 'token_version' in user DB; reject tokens with old version
Yes, requires DB lookup (often cached heavily to mitigate perf hit)
Pure stateless (fast, hard to revoke) vs Stateful check (revocable, slower)

q: Is a Hybrid (Stateless access, Stateful refresh) common?
o: Yes, very common balance (fast API access, secure session control)
Decode just parses Base64; Verify checks signature and expiry

q: Always set an _____ time for access tokens.
Is decoding a JWT safe without key?
o: Safe to READ payload, but NOT to trust it (it could be forged)

q: The 'azp' claim should match the client ID if verifiable.
Usually, the padding character _____ is omitted in Base64Url.
Can you use JWT for password reset?
o: Yes, embed user ID and short expiry, sign it, send in link

q: What happens if secret is changed?
o: All previously issued tokens signed with old secret become invalid immediately
Key ID used to match the signing key in the set
Array of JSON Web Key objects
Yes, allows rotation (current key, future key, past key)

q: Azure Key Vault or AWS KMS can be used to manage signing _____.
The 'unprotected' member contains header parameters that are not _____ protection.
RS256 is preferred for _____ architectures where multiple services verify tokens.
If the principal is not the entity that authenticated, you might need a separate 'act' (_____) claim.

o: Public Key Use (sig = signing, enc = encryption)

q: What is 'n' and 'e' in RSA JWK?

o: To prove the key belongs to a specific entity via PKI chain
To prevent cross-JWT confusion (e.g. confusing access token with ID token)

q: Can JWT be used for Session ID container?
o: Yes, payload can just contain 'session_id: xyz'

q: Short expiration times limit the window of opportunity for a _____ token.

o: OIDC scope requesting a Refresh Token (access when user is not present)

q: What does a JWT looking like 'ey...' indicate?
o: It's a JWS Compact Serialization (starts with encoded header)

q: What is 'Timing Attack' on verify signature?
o: If string comparison is not constant-time, attacker can guess signature byte-by-byte based on response time

q: Signing a token does not hide its contents; only _____ does that.
JWTs are a good choice for stateless authentication.
It is safe to skip expiration checks for internal tokens.
A digital signature provides functionality similar to a physical _____/seal.

o: If the random nonce 'k' is reused for two different signatures, the private key can be recovered

q: OpenID Connect ID Tokens are a specific type of _____.

o: Generating 'k' deterministically from the message and private key to avoid RNG failures
The signer cannot deny having signed the message (only possible with Asymmetric keys)
No, because both signer and verifier share the secret key (verifier could have forged it)
Yes, provided the private key wasn't stolen
Passed as Metadata (Binary Headers or ASCII Headers), often with 'CallCredentials'
Sent in initial handshake (Query param or Header) or first message

q: The payload is encrypted by default.
Risk of JWT in Query Param (WebSocket)?
o: Token logs in server access logs and browser history (Leakage)

q: Mitigation for WebSocket Query Param leak?
o: Use 'ticket' pattern (exchange JWT for short-lived ticket via API, use ticket in WS URL)

q: Can you use JWT in IoT?

Issuer. Who created the token (e.g. https://auth.google.com).
Subject. The user/entity the token is about (e.g. User ID).

Not Before. Token is invalid BEFORE this time.
Issued At. Time when token was created. Used to determine age.
JWT ID. Unique identifier for the token. Used to prevent replay.
